close_symbols: OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler (declaration: the function-pointer member and its exact prototype/type)
All functions that may be be assigned to OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler (the full definitions/implementations of each possible handler)
The site(s) where EventHandler is assigned/registered (source locations or symbols that perform the assignment/registration)
Any global objects referenced within the EventHandler implementations (their definitions) and any functions they call
explanation: To determine whether the target function violates the MISRA C for-loop well‑formedness rule we must examine any for loops whose behaviour is considered part of the target function. OS_NotifyEvent itself contains no loops, but it calls through a function pointer (OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler). The rule explicitly counts the behaviour of called functions as part of the loop body, so any for loops inside the EventHandler implementations (or in functions they call) are relevant. Therefore we need: (1) the definition of OS_SharedGlobalVars and the exact declaration/type of its EventHandler member so we can identify the correct prototype and locate all call targets; (2) the full definitions/implementations of every function that can be assigned to EventHandler so their for loops (if any) can be examined for loop counter usage and side effects; (3) the source sites where EventHandler is set/registered to find all possible handler assignments; (4) OS_SUCCESS constant so the return semantics are clear; (5) the type definitions for OS_Event_t and osal_id_t because loop counters or loop-control objects in handlers may involve these types or their aliases; and (6) any global objects referenced inside those handler implementations (and the definitions of functions those handlers call) because the MISRA rule prohibits loop conditions or increments that use objects modified in the loop body or by called functions. Having these symbols allows a complete analysis of any for loops that are part of the target function's observable behaviour.
